Murder, sex and divorce: Popes of the past

19/03/2013

As Pope Francis takes his place as the new leader of global Catholicism, Shaun Richardson looks back at a small selection of these Popes and the events that marked their offices.

Image by

By undefined undefined

Over the past two thousand years, the Catholic Church has undergone radical changes but one thing has stayed the same - it has always been headed by a Pope. Every man (and arguably the single woman) who has rattled the keys of Saint Peter has provoked debate and opinion amongst Clergy and Laity alike. Each has brought their own unique style to the papal office, ranging from murder to martyrdom, and thus opinion of the popes has fluctuated between reverence and resentment.

Papal pregnancy and public persecution

Although never proven, there are claims that a 'popess' once resided on the papal throne. In the mid-9th century, a woman called Joan is said to have disguised herself as a man, getting herself promoted through the ranks of Cardinal to become head of the Church. In the 13th century, stories arose about a Pope Joan who came to office in 855, which are said to have been taken as undisputed fact by the 15th century. It is said that, two years into her alleged reign, Joan gave birth. This was apparently made a public event as a way of punishing Joan for her deception and, if legend is to be believed, she was then publicly stoned and killed. Historians are sceptical about how realistic the Joan story is but, with so much debate, literature and paintings centred on the topic, it is unlikely that there is not some truth in such claims.

Taking the skeletons out of the closet

Pope Stephen VI was not content to let the past remain buried so, early on in his reign during 897, he decided to put his predecessor, Pope Formosus, on trial for perjury, violating Church Cannons and planning to reclaim the papacy. This was in response to increasing hostility from factions who had supported Formosus. Whilst this does not initially seem a strange act, it takes on a whole new perspective when we consider that Formosus had been dead and lying in the ground for 9 months when he was put on trial. Yet, this did not stop Stephen from having the corpse exhumed, clothed in papal robes and sat up in court. The convicted party was oddly silent throughout the proceedings, after which he had three fingers cut off and was thrown into the River Tiber. This so-called "Cadaver Synod" was the starting gun for over two decades of disputes between Cardinals who were in the running for the papacy. Stephen did not achieve the outcome he had hoped for; he was stripped of the papacy, imprisoned as a monk and strangled to death before the year was out.

Have you got the balls to be Pope?

Unbeknown to many worshippers, a seemingly respectable ritual of conclave that persisted until the mid 20th century may have its origins in a much more undignified past. Before Pope John Paul I abandoned the papal coronation in 1978, post-conclave rituals involved each Cardinal kneeling in front of the Pope, who was sat in the 'sedia gestatoria', to whom they paid homage. However, this is a descendant of another tradition, which originally was a functional element to papal initiation. Until Pope Pius V's papacy in 1566, it has been argued that newly elected popes sat in two thrones. In the first, they received various items that were symbolic of power over Rome and Catholicism. Dignitaries kissed the Pope's feet, paying acts of homage, as Cardinals continued to do after the 16th century. However, the Pope then lay down in the second throne, the 'sedes seracatoria', which allegedly had a hole in the seat - one of which is said to be stored in the Vatican museum today. The Pope was then allegedly approached by a deacon who examined what lay below the hole of the seat to ensure that everything was in working order, proclaiming "pontificalia habet et bene pendentes, dignum est papali coronae", which translates to "he has pontifical equipment and they are hanging well, worthy is the papal crown". In essence this rite, the 'ostentatio genitalium', was a test of manhood. It is said to have been created during the 11th century, somewhere between the reign of Benedict IX and Paschal II, although debate persists over its motivation. Some argue that it was a safeguard to prevent females from becoming pope, following Joan's alleged escapade as episcopate of Rome. Others believe it was a way of adhering to Old Testament teachings, that a woman could never take the reins of the Church. Whatever the truth is, it is likely that the facts are lost forever.

Love on the rock; well, it ain't no surprise!

The early Church was dominated by successfully corrupt popes. However, this was not just in the form of hushed up allegations of cover ups that we see today, but visible demonstrations of non-celibacy, incest and prostitution, with many of these clearly referenced in Vatican archives. Most notably was John XII, who became Pope in 955, and allegedly turned the Lateran Palace, the early residence of the Pope, into a brothel. This exceptionally damaged Pope entered office at the tender age of 8 years old and, as is the case of many modern day celebrities, fame too young corrupted him for life. Fortunately for the modern papacy, allegations of such sexual misconduct no longer blight the centre of the Church and most, although not all, have been wiped from the Catholic world. The Patrologia Latina, an ongoing anthology of texts written from the year 200 up to 1216, claims that John practiced Pagan rituals and refused to make the sign of the cross. Whilst this would not be overly damaging for the average individual, John was the Pope, it was his job to ensure Catholics remained devoted to God. Consequently, this activity was akin to a university lecturer playing the Teletubbies for a lecture's duration or a doctor dishing out complementary burgers to all their patients - it completely undermined his role! Yet the scandal did not stop there. John also adulterated married women; he murdered, blinded and castrated Cardinals and Bishops; he even committed intercourse upon the tomb of St Peter!

Bitter rivalry and a sweet defeat

Clement II was not short of enemies. He threatened excommunication for any Clergyman undermining his Church reforms and he was in talks with those who advocated a radical crack down on Clerical abuses, such as St Peter Damian. Therefore, his death in 1047 can quite easily be put down to unexplained circumstances or, to put it less euphemistically, an unscrupulous Bishop chucking Clement off the throne so that that he could get his hands on world domination. In 1959 the certainties of science confirmed the conspiracies of history, when the testing of Clement's bones revealed that he had been poisoned by lead sugar. Absorption of lead into the body takes at least two weeks to kill an individual, as it first accumulates in the bones before beginning to build up in the bloodstream, where it alters DNA and destroys cells. Therefore, we can assume that Clement's death was not a spontaneous attack and somebody had been planning this 'Whodunnit' for a long time.

How a Hertford boy entered the Holy Office

Whether it is Eurovision or the World Cup, Britain has always seemed to play second fiddle to other nations in international competition and the papacy is no exception. However, the papacy of Adrian IV from 1154 to 1159, the only Englishman to reach the heights of Catholic stardom, allowed England a single chance to show off its moves on the papal stage and bask in the heavenly limelight. Adrian was born Nicholas Breakspeare in Hertfordhire,in around 1100. Initially he was rejected from his local Abbey. Not put off by this early stumble, Breakspeare travelled to France, where he studied and entered a French monastery. From this platform, his career took off. The humble son of an impoverished upbringing was promoted to a Bishop and a Cardinal, due to his skill and knowledge, and his route to meritocracy led to him be tasked by Pope Eugenius III with reforming the Catalonian and Scandinavian Churches. When Eugenius died, Breakspeare became Adrian IV, inheriting not only the Holy Office but the heap of problems that came with it. Nevertheless, he successfully steered Rome through its volatile relationship with the Holy Roman Emperor and actively worked to reform secular aspects of the Church.

A divorce rejection and a new religion

When Henry VIII, King of England, set his sights on Anne Boleyn in 1526, there was small snag - he was already married. It is unclear why he wanted to throw in the towel with his first marriage to his brother's widow, Catherine of Aragon. Was it her failure to conceive a male heir that delivered the knockout blow? Was it due to Henry's belief that the marriage was unlawful that he called time-out? Was it Anne's insistence that they marry before she fulfilled Henry's physical desires? What is clear is that Henry expected a quick divorce from his betrothal to Catherine but, as he found out when he appealed to Pope Clement VII for an annulment in 1527, this would not be the case. Armed with an arsenal of scripture and theology, Henry and his ministers set about trying to convince the Pope that his marriage to his Catherine was unlawful and was never valid. However, Clement refused Henry's appeals and installed Lorenzo Campeggio as papal envoy in England, who was tasked with preventing an annulment going ahead. Clement's stance was exasperated by the fact that, following the Sac of Rome, he was under the control of the Holy Roman Emperor, Charles V. Since Charles V was Catherine's nephew, the Pope was not inclined to further upset him by granting Henry permission to discard Charles' aunty. Subsequently, in 1534, Henry's Chief Minister Thomas Cromwell forced through the Act of Supremacy, declaring the English sovereign supreme head of the English Church and "Fidei Defensor" (or "defender of the faith" - still visible on coins today). This resulted in the Pope excommunicating England and it induced the conception of the Anglican Church alongside Catholicism, which marked the beginning of over 250 years of religious conflict across Britain.

The Pope that dodged death...twice

On the 13th May 1981, Pope John Paul II made his way through a crowded St Peter's square, greeted by cheers. Yet one individual amongst the crowds, Mehmet Ali Agca, had more sinister ambitions - he possessed a gun and he intended to kill. Agca shot the Pope four times, hospitalising him and nearly causing his death. Fortunately, John Paul survived the assassination attempt, even going as far as to forgive his attacker. Whilst the basic events are clear, however, the details of who masterminded the plot and what their reasoning was to remain as murky as the legends surrounding the medieval Church. Various groups have been blamed including the Soviet KGB, Islamic terrorists and as recent as February 2013, there have been reports that the Iranian Supreme Leader was involved. Curiously, there is a prophecy know as 'The Third Secret of Fatima', allegedly made to three girls by the Virgin Mary during an apparition in 1917, which predicted the assassination of the Pope. Some believe that the attempted assassination of John Paul was simply a fulfilment of this prophecy. In 1982, John Paul was victim to a second assassination attempt by Juan Fernandez y Krohn, who attacked the Pope with a bayonet. The Pope again survived, although, at the time, this second attack was less publicised and only in 2008 was it revealed that the Pope was actually injured by Krohn.
